quiz.title: Unit 1 Quiz: Foundations of Macroeconomics
quiz.subtitle: Scarcity, Opportunity Cost, Production Possibilities, Comparative Advantage, and Basic Economic Systems
quiz.subject: AP Macroeconomics

questions.question: Scarcity in economics refers to
options: A shortage of goods in a market
questions.explanation: Scarcity is the fundamental economic problem: unlimited human wants in a world of limited resources, requiring choices and trade-offs.

questions.question: The opportunity cost of a decision is
options: The money spent on the chosen option
The total cost of all alternatives
The value of the next best alternative forgone
The cost of producing one more unit
The explicit financial outlay of the decision
questions.explanation: Opportunity cost is the value of the best alternative given up when a choice is made. It includes both explicit and implicit costs.

questions.question: If a country must give up 5 tons of corn to produce 1 ton of wheat, the opportunity cost of 1 ton of wheat is
questions.explanation: Opportunity cost = what is given up / what is gained. Giving up 5 corn for 1 wheat means 1 wheat costs 5 corn.

questions.question: A point inside the production possibilities curve (PPC) indicates
questions.explanation: Points inside the PPC are attainable but inefficient—resources are underutilized or unemployed.

questions.question: Economic growth is shown on a PPC diagram as
options: A shift of the curve outward
A shift of the curve inward
A change in the slope of the curve
questions.explanation: Economic growth expands productive capacity, shifting the PPC outward. More of both goods can be produced.

questions.question: A straight‑line PPC implies
questions.explanation: A linear PPC means resources are perfectly adaptable; opportunity cost remains constant as production shifts.

questions.question: The law of increasing opportunity costs results from
options: Resources being equally suited to all uses
questions.explanation: As more of one good is produced, resources less suited to that good must be used, raising opportunity cost (bowed‑out PPC).

questions.question: Which of the following would shift a country's PPC outward?
options: A reallocation of resources toward consumer goods
An increase in the labor force
questions.explanation: Increasing resources (labor, capital) or improving technology shifts PPC outward. Reducing unemployment moves to the curve, not shifting it.

questions.question: Absolute advantage is determined by
options: Higher productivity per unit of input
Greater total output of all goods
Lower production costs in monetary terms
questions.explanation: Absolute advantage: who can produce more of a good with the same resources (or same output with fewer resources).

questions.question: Comparative advantage exists when a country can produce a good
options: Using fewer resources than another country
At a lower opportunity cost than another country
Of higher quality than another country
At a lower financial cost than another country
questions.explanation: Comparative advantage is about lower opportunity cost, not absolute productivity. It's the basis for mutually beneficial trade.

questions.question: If Country A produces 10 cars or 5 trucks, and Country B produces 12 cars or 6 trucks,
options: Country A has comparative advantage in cars
Country B has comparative advantage in trucks
Country B has absolute advantage in both
Trade will not benefit either country
questions.explanation: Country B produces more cars (12>10) and more trucks (6>5) with same resources → absolute advantage in both. Need opportunity costs to find comparative advantage.

questions.question: Mutually beneficial trade is possible when
options: One country has absolute advantage in both goods
Each country specializes in the good where it has comparative advantage
questions.explanation: Even if one country is absolutely better at both, both gain by specializing in their comparative advantage and trading.

questions.question: In a market economy, resource allocation is primarily determined by
questions.explanation: Market economies rely on decentralized decisions: consumers vote with dollars, producers seek profit, prices signal scarcity.

questions.question: The 'invisible hand' concept refers to
options: How self‑interest in markets can promote social welfare
questions.explanation: Adam Smith's metaphor: individuals pursuing self‑interest in competitive markets are led, as if by an invisible hand, to promote social good.

questions.question: Which is a characteristic of a command economy?
options: Prices set by supply and demand
questions.explanation: Command economies: government owns resources, decides what/how/for whom to produce. Prices are set, not market‑determined.

questions.question: Consumer goods differ from capital goods in that consumer goods
options: Are used to produce other goods
questions.explanation: Consumer goods satisfy wants directly (food, clothes). Capital goods (machines, tools) are used to produce other goods.

questions.question: Investing in capital goods today will likely result in
options: Outward shift of the PPC in the future
Higher unemployment in the short run
questions.explanation: Capital goods expand future productive capacity → PPC shifts outward. Sacrificing current consumption for future growth.

questions.question: If the production of pizzas and robots is shown on a PPC, and a country chooses more pizzas and fewer robots, in the future the PPC will
questions.explanation: Choosing consumption (pizzas) over investment (robots) reduces future capital stock → slows growth, may shift PPC inward relative to investing.

questions.question: A mixed economy combines elements of
questions.explanation: Mixed economy: primarily market‑based, with government intervention to correct market failures, provide public goods, redistribute income.

questions.question: Which statement about opportunity cost is true?
options: It is always measured in monetary terms
It is zero when resources are unemployed
It exists even when no money is exchanged
questions.explanation: Opportunity cost is the value of forgone alternatives, whether monetary or not (e.g., time, leisure). It exists in all decisions involving scarce resources.

scoreMessages.90: Strong grasp of foundational concepts: scarcity, PPC, comparative advantage.
scoreMessages.70: Good understanding; review opportunity cost calculations and PPC shifts.
scoreMessages.50: Basic recall; focus on comparative vs. absolute advantage and PPC analysis.
scoreMessages.0: Needs review: scarcity, trade‑offs, PPC, economic systems.
